title: Ticket #1681: shared_port deadlocking
description:
In Igor's large-scale tests of condor_shared_port, we observed that the schedd often failed to send a heartbeat to the master, resulting in the master thinking that the schedd was hung.

This appears to be caused by a temporary deadlock between the schedd and condor_shared_port. If all of the shared_port workers (SHARED_PORT_MAX_WORKERS=50) are busy, the shared_port server will attempt to service the next incoming request in the main process. If, at the same time, the schedd is doing a blocking connect through the shared_port server, the two processes can deadlock.

<131.225.191.183:58965>: No such file or directory

Connection reset by peer, reading 5 bytes from <131.225.206.93:0>.

09/28/10 12:24:56 SharedPortClient: failed to receive result for
SHARED_PORT_PASS_FD to /home/igorschedd/glidecondor/condor_local/log/daemon_sock
/28067_7d8e_1074 as requested by STARTD
<131.225.191.175:50593?CCBID=131.225.206.102:7704#3996> on
<131.225.191.175:34026>: Connection reset by peer

Workaround

Set SHARED_PORT_MAX_WORKERS so large that it never runs out or set NOT_RESPONDING_TIMEOUT very large.

How to Fix

  1. [DONE] Use a non-blocking connect in SendAliveToParent(), because blocking connects between daemons are always sources of trouble, even without shared_port.

  2. In the shared_port server, create a queue for each target and only process N at a time from each queue where N is small compared to SHARED_PORT_MAX_WORKERS. If daemon A needs to connect to daemon B, it will not be possible for all of the workers to be blocked on daemon A and thus deadlock is avoided.
